feed.title: mymind
feed.subtitle: Miftah Ahmad Choiri is an IT Infrastructure Specialist with expertise in Linux system administration, virtualization, and automation. He has experience working with Red Hat, HP-UX, AIX, and AS/400 environments, along with OpenShift, Ansible, and shell scripting. Passionate about on-premises and cloud computing, Miftah is always eager to expand his knowledge and contribute to innovative IT solutions.

entry.title: New Post Miftah Redhat
entry.content:
Hi, Miftah… You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: Hi, Miftah… You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.
